ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the importance Moscow had in the development of Modernism, and the cultural exchange that occurred between Paris and Russia throughout the late 19th and early 20th centuries. I also learned how to analyze artwork, which I had never done before. Further, I gained a general understanding of the growth of Modernism, and how difficult/contentious it is to categorize, date, or study it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was very well organized. Each week was devoted to a group of ideas, movements, artists, thinkers, etc. The course was designed so that it was very easy for students to make connections between ideas in different weeks. It also exposed me to many new ideas (I had never taken any course similar to this). Sometimes the course devolved into a "Leminar," where the 10 of us were sitting in a classroom listening to the professor lecture. I think, perhaps, it may be easier to design this course as a lecture, but then you would lose some of the collaborative elements.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. If you are interested in any humanities discipline, this course will be intriguing. It spans so many disciplines, from history to literature to art history to film studies to theatre studies, etc. Further, the study of Modernism is crucial to understanding Europe in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Every class was exciting, which I cannot say for most of my classes.
